first_reasoning: The Industrial Products division has exhibited a clearer growth trajectory and offers more direct, high-leverage applications for R&D funds—material science and process automation projects that translate quickly into cost savings and margin expansion. In contrast, the Consumer Products unit is mature, flatlining, and would require high-risk breakthrough innovations to reverse its trend. Allocating the ten-million to Industrial maximizes the potential for a timely, measurable earnings turnaround.
second_reasoning: Allocating eight million to Consumer allows two distinct concept streams plus a lean market pilot, providing enough runway to vet breakthrough ideas without overcommitting resources. At the same time, twelve million in Industrial targets proven margin drivers—advanced materials trials and automation roll-outs—where we’ve already seen reliable returns. This split balances the higher-risk, binary upside of consumer innovation with the more predictable cost-reduction gains in industrial, maximizing our chance of reversing losses and driving sustained earnings recovery.
